seg.seg: [8d] The one having relied on body and mind the inhaling and exhaling ...

For they haverealized (the fourth Dhyāna). No-one breathes out, [9d] who has not realized the fourth Dhyāna. The mind becomes all feeble. Turned towards the inside his thought and feeling his whole body is in a trance.

For such reasons there is no exhaling for these. [10d] To which place the body belongs, to the earth [also] belongs [its] exhaling. For the wind must be understood as naiṣyandika [“belonging to the discharge (of the body)”]. There is [also] the aupacayika [“coming from nourishment”],

also the vipākaya [“originating in the compensation for the deeds”]. But this does not count in exhaling. [11d] Knowledge of this, this recognize as the nature of the root of merit, for the consciousness has received the power in the section (lit. group), be-

-cause of this it is called ānāpānasṃrti. This is the gate of immortality for the one having sharp senses. [12d] This [is] connected to the sensual shaped [“rūpa”] and [the world] as wished [“kāma”] world. The sensual world must be

be taken care of. If it [the ānāpānasṃrti] the one that takes refuge in the five Bhūmis [“earths”] with the indifferent senses can be evoked, then this one [the world as wished] should evoked it [the ānāpānasṃrti] at all times. [13d] In a six-fold way is this inhaling and exhaling being called: counting after [“gaṇanā”]

going towards [“anugama”], looking up [“upalakṣanā”], placing [“sthāna”], turning [“vivartanā”] [and] purity [“pariśuddhi”]. As having sixteen ways this meditation is called. [14d] The counting here is called fivefold: counting
Als sechzehn Erscheinungsformen habend wird diese Versenkung gelehrt.
As having sixteen forms of appearance this meditation is taught.
Das Zählen, das wird hier in fünf Erscheinungsformen gelehrt: [Richtig] zählen, weniger, mehr, Mischen und Reinhalten.
Counting is taught in five variants here: counting [correctly], less, more, mixing, and keeping pure.

Das Zählen wird hier in fünf Erscheinungsformen gelehrt: [Richtig] Zählen, weniger, mehr, Mischen und Reinhalten. ... Reinhalten ist: Fünf[mal] atmet er ein [und] zählt das [als] fünf, oder fünfmal atmet er aus [und] zählt das ebenfalls [als] fünf.

Counting is taught here in five forms of appearance: counting [correctly], less, more, mixing and keeping pure. ... Keeping pure [is this]: five [times] he inhales [and] counts this [as] five, or five times he exhales [and] also counts this [as] five.
less, more, mixing and purity. Counting [, this is] one, two, three, four, five to ten. Again [and again] he counts others as inhaling, ten by ten. [15d] Counting less, however, [is] here: Seven,

eight or ten [times] he exhales, but he calls [only] six, five or nine, [but] not the full amount. More counting furthermore [is] here: How often he exhales, he counts [it] less than that as exhaling [16d]. Mixing

Mehr zählen ferner [ist] hier: Wie oft er ausatmet, zählt er weniger als das als Ausatmen. Vermischen [ist]: Was er ausatmet, das fasst er [als] Einatmen auf, oder [was] er einatmet, zählt er [als] Ausatmen.

Counting more, furthermore, [is] here: As often as he exhales, he counts less than that as exhaling. Mixing [is]: What he exhales, he regards [as] inhaling, or [what] he inhales, he counts [as] exhaling.

[is this]: What he exhales, he understands as inhaling, or [what] he inhales, he counts [as] exhaling. Purity [is this]: five [times] he inhales [and] counts this as five, or five times he breathes out [and] also counts this as five.

[17d] Following the wind, furthermore, [is this]: when he inhales through the nose [and] the wind enters him, he follows it. With consciousness and knowledge he follows the wind: into the throat, into the navel, towards the heart down into the feet.
Going after the wind is: when he inhales through the nose and the wind enters inside him, [then] it goes after it. (cf : ii, 61)

[18d] [All the way] to the big toe he leads the consciousness, from there he sees the winds emerging from the big toe, half a sesame-seed or a [whole] sesame-seed in measure, [the length of] one finger,

one span or one arm having come [out]. [19d] As far as his mind’s power [will allow], as far as his sensual organs, so far he sees. How then is, furthermore, the placing of the winds? [Answer:] Having entered by the nose

the winds he places in the throat, in the heart, towards the navel or in the big toe. [20d] The winds having come upwards he places in the crown of the head, until he sees all winds standing in the body, as if locked in. Like a jewel on a string

the body he sees. In this way understand the placing of the winds. [21d] Looking up [is this]: The winds having entered by the nose, those he sees having come to the throat, [having] come to the navel, (having come)
to the (heart) unto the big toe. Then from such a one is ...

p.note: In b1 instead of 'five' one would expect 'seven', and 'less than that' should probably read 'more than that'.

This leaf, which, according to leaf number and content, belongs to the Smṛtivarga (XV), in strophes 9-22 contained in it deals with the ānāpānasmṛti, the meditation relating to breathing in and out. On this matter cf. Abhidh-k 6, p. 153ff. The metre is 14/11/11/11 syllables in the rhythm 7/7 and 7/4.
The original manuscript is missing, but, like and (alongside which it was found) was damaged only at the top edge and otherweise almost complete. Contained leaf number 220.
According to 75 fn. 4 the reading =etsñai should be corrected to =etswai in the transcription.
According to 75 fn. 5 the reading alyaṇkäṃ should be corrected to alyeṇkäṃ in the transcription.
According to 76 fn. 1 the reading satāṣṣä should be corrected to satāṣṣä(ṃ) in the transcription, also yāmastär to yamastär.
According to 76 fn. 3 the verse interpunction is missing after ṣaṃṣträ and ṣiś should be corrected to piś.

Translation

General remarks

This leaf, which, according to leaf number and content, belongs to the Smṛtivarga (XV), in strophes 9-22 contained in it deals with the ānāpānasmṛti, the meditation relating to breathing in and out. On this matter cf. Abhidh-k 6, p. 153ff. The metre is 14/11/11/11 syllables in the rhythm 7/7 and 7/4.
The original manuscript is missing, but, like [[THT 31]] and [[THT 3]] (alongside which it was found) was damaged only at the top edge and otherweise almost complete. Contained leaf number 220.
